title: 106_hr583
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act, titled "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998," amends the Civil Service Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of a law enforcement officer. The Act amends the Civil Service Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys as law enforcement officers under the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The Act amends the Civil Service Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys as law enforcement officers under the Federal Employees' Retirement System. Paragraph (17) of section 8401 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include Assistant United States Attorneys as eligible for retirement benefits. The Act amends the Civil Service Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys as law enforcement officers under the Federal Employees' Retirement System. It defines "Assistant United States Attorney" and specifies the effective date of the Act and its amendments. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. For the purposes of this section, an incumbent is an individual appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of this Act and serving in that capacity on such date. The Department of Justice must provide notice to incumbents about their election rights under this Act within 6 months of its effective date. Incumbents have the option to make an election under this Act. An incumbent appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the Act's effective date can choose to be treated according to the amendments or as if the Act never existed. Failure to elect on time is treated as an election under the amendments made by the Act. The deadline for making this election is specified. Failure to timely elect under this subsection is treated as an election made on the last allowable day. The deadline for the election is before the 90th day after the notice is provided or the incumbent separates from service. No change in retirement coverage occurs before the Act's enactment for any incumbent. Interim status provision ensures no change in retirement coverage for incumbents until they elect the new option. Retroactive effect applies to service performed after the election date. (e) Makeup Contributions.--
Makeup contributions are required for service performed before the effective date of the election under applicable provisions of chapter 83 or 84 of title 5, United States Code. Makeup contributions are required for service performed before the effective date of the election under applicable provisions of chapter 83 or 84 of title 5, United States Code. The Department of Justice must remit the amount to the Office of Personnel Management as required. The Department of Justice must remit additional individual and Government contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund to the Office of Personnel Management, which will then deposit the amount in the Treasury of the United States. The Department of Justice must remit additional contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund for Assistant United States Attorneys, including interest, as required by the amendments made by this Act. Individual liability is not imposed by this Act or by title 5 of the United States Code. The amendments made by this Act require the Department of Justice to remit additional contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund for Assistant United States Attorneys, along with interest. No individual liability is imposed by this Act or by title 5 of the United States Code. The Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations for implementing this Act, including determining interest on the required contributions. The Act requires the Department of Justice to remit contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund for Assistant United States Attorneys, with provisions for determining interest. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" is defined as an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28, United States Code.
